title: Pronunciation of "Shikadi"?
content:
I've been wondering this for too much time already, so I ask you here.
How do you pronounce "Shikadi"?

I for one have been pronunciating it for years the same way you'd pronounce it if it was pure spanish. i.e.

shikadi /shee-kah-dee(short)/

On the same topic, how do you pronounce "gannalech"?------------------------------
[url=http://shadowm2006.sitesled.com/]My website[/url]
[url=http://p072.ezboard.com/fpubliccommanderkeenforumfrm20.showMessage?topicID=12.topic]Get Windows/Linux native LModKeen 2 with integrated FIN2BMP![/url]. You know you want to.

title: hehe
content:
Back when I was younger, I pronounced it "Shick(like Quick)-uh-DIE(rhymes with Guy). That makes it somewhat awkward to say out loud, but when I was 10, I didn't even consider that there'd be alternate ways of saying it.

When TMST did his "phone call to Billy Blaze" thing some time ago, (2002?) he pronounced it Shi-KAH-dee (Shi like the first part of "ship" but without the P, KAH like "car" without the R, and dee like deep, without the P. I've been pronouncing it that way ever since, because it flows better, and sounds cooler!

title: Re: hehe
content:
Uh, curiously that's exactly the same way I've been pronouncing it since discovering Keen 4.

Tom Hall never spoke about this I guess. (or did he?)------------------------------

content:
I've always pronounced it the TMST way.

I guess Gannalech would have to sound something like "Grand Intellect". GAN-uh-Lek (a as in can, uh as in uh, e as in set).________________

title: Shrek Car Die
content:
Shikadi: "Shi[p]-caddy". Gannalech: "G([f]an)-aleK".

I used to pronounce Intellect emphasising the middle syllable, "intellect". I'd not come across the word before playing Keen, and didn't realise its meaning.

It bugs me when I'm not told how to pronounce names in works of fiction, especially novels where you might encounter the name thousands of times.

[hr]bp But... I did use to call the Vorticons the Victorians.[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-lol.gif[/img]
[hr]That is amusing.

title: Re: Shrek Car Die
content:
I'm in Japanese 3-4 at my school, so when something 'foreign' ia spelled a certain way, I just use the Japanese pronounciation.

Shee-Kah-Dii.[hr][img]http://img53.imageshack.us/img53/6843/cksighu8.png[/img]Swim
Swim
Hungry

title: Re: Shrek Car Die
content:
It seems that the spanglish pronunciation is the more used here.
But, talking about length of syllables:
Shikadi /shee (short) -kah (short) -dee (short) /
------------------------------

title: lol
content: What's the difference between Sha-kaddy and Shuh-kaddy, then, when spoken out loud quickly?  They're identical, to me.  Maybe you're reading the Sha as "Shay?"

title: Re: lol
content:
When I first came across the word Shikadi I pronounced it "SHICK-a-dee", but now I say "Shi-KAH-dee". Also I pronounce Gannalech "GAN-a-leck"."A man is the less likely to become great the more he is dominated by reason: few can achieve greatness - and none in art - if they are not dominated by illusion."
--Mr. Doctor

title: Re: lol
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]What's the difference between Sha-kaddy and Shuh-kaddy, then, when spoken out loud quickly? They're identical, to me.[hr][/quote]
None, which is why we're having this discussion. If you're putting the stress on the second syllable, any vowel will make that noise. Letters, as written, could mean all kinds of things. If we're talking about phonetics, we'd better use "canonical pronunciations", or we're getting nowhere. "A" has four reasonable meanings (I'm basing this on my dictionary), but a schwa is not usually one of them.________________
[img]http://img80.imageshack.us/img80/8498/missouriansf9.png[/img]

title: Re: Spaz ate the Dopefish
content:
The difference is...

Robocop never misses. Ever. In one of the movies he shoots someone holding a woman hostage by calculating the ricochet off of a metal wall. That's skill. Robored shoots a volley of shots and then has to look and see if it hit anything.

Robo RED has nothing to do with Robo COP. Robocop is a human that was turned cyborg and like... overcomes his original programming. Robo red is an awesome sci-fi security robot design.

Oh and Robocop has a brain.



Could anyone tell I was a huge fan of Robocop as a child? [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-crazy.gif[/img] -----------------------
The end of this post. You may stop reading now.

title: Pronouncing-ness
content:
I always have trouble saying Blooguard for some raisin. I'm sure there's probably only one way to pronounce it, but it always comes out sounding like "Blue Guard."

I used to pronounce Shikadi like SHIH-kuh-dee. After watching the Shadowlands series and stuff, I found that the Shih-KAH-dee was much more fun. My sister thinks it's stupid, but I think otherwise.

Gannalech, I generally pronounce more or less how it looks: GA (rhyming with the sheep noise) nuh-lech.

I say orbatrix like OR-buh-trix. It's cool that way.

Shockshund, I pronounced for the longest time like Shock-shund. I'm amazed by how long it took me to figure out that it's a play on Dachshund. (Which I was also once unable to say right.) [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-shockshund.gif[/img]

And just out of curiosity, how is Gnosticus supposed to be pronounced? I always say, "NOSS (rhymes w/ boss)-tih-kuss."

content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]I always have trouble saying Blooguard for some raisin.[hr][/quote]

I've always been an orb-a-trix 'er assuming the end has the same latin root.

Gnosticus I've always said like KT.[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v499/Nevad/menbun.gif[/img]

content:
Hey, wondering if the Keeninverse names could be translated or kept as they are if put in a foreign language text. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smoke.gif[/img] Has anybody thought about this?------------------------------

title: Re: translatable?
content:
Probably just the made up names, like Yorp, Shikadi, and Vorticon*. Not ones like Poison Slug, Robo Red, etc, although, in another language, it probably just adds to the alien-ness of the game... [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]


*Is the name vorticon made up? I remember reading a book about aliens when I was little, and there were guys called vortics or something (although they were shapeshifters, not blue dogs...)-Genius314

title: Re: translatable?
content:
I've read "Vorticon" translated as "Vorticones" to spanish (spec. spanish wikipedia). I dislike that.

RoboRed could be translated to Spanish as "RoboRojo", but I prefer "RoboRed" as it sounds like "RoboCop" (which is not translated). Slicestar... it's just a star which slices, right? Shockshound could be "Shikabueso" or something, as *hound in spanish are translated as "sabueso-"something.

Commander Keen can be translated to Spanish as "Comandante Entusiasta" if I assume Keen is synonym of "enthusiast" in English.

Shikadi (if it's the right pronunciation, btw) sounds a lot like "chick" (spanish: "chica") with a shh sound instead of ch. (/tsh/?). Wait a second... and if they are female actually? [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-freud.gif[/img]

I can't recall, but what pronoun is used to refer to a single shikadi in the Keen games? His? Her? Or what? I only remember plural references (they).------------------------------
[url=http://shadowm2006.sitesled.com/]My website[/url]
[url=http://p072.ezboard.com/fpubliccommanderkeenforumfrm20.showMessage?topicID=12.topic]Get Windows/Linux native LModKeen 2 with integrated FIN2BMP![/url]. You know you want to.
[url=http://shadowm2006.sitesled.com/meta/projectpage.htm]The META engine for 2D games[/url].

title: Re: translatable?
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]I can't recall, but what pronoun is used to refer to a single shikadi in the Keen games? His? Her? Or what? I only remember plural references (they).[hr][/quote]

None. They're only referred to plurally. What I just noticed, though, is that some enemies are described as "they," while others, such as Robo Red and Shelley, are referred to with "he" and "she."-Genius314

title: Re: translatable?
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]*Is the name vorticon made up? I remember reading a book about aliens when I was little, and there were guys called vortics or something (although they were shapeshifters, not blue dogs...)[hr][/quote]

Dr Who has et Vortisaurs, and there are Vortins in a book I was reading, but the closest thing I could find was in the copy of one of my old 'Tales of Extraordinary Interest' comics which has a race of iron eating metal balls called Vorticae. (They compete with some strange ugly hedgehog things called splatterbang on a planet of the same name.)

[quote]Quote:[hr]Hey, wondering if the Keeninverse names could be translated or kept as they are if put in a foreign language text. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smoke.gif[/img] Has anybody thought about this?[hr][/quote]

*Well, Alice made up some German names for the Keen 4 characters I like:

Tiernu(Arachnut) Wtenden(Berkeloid) Blauvogel(Blue Bird) Springer(Bounder) Ohnatem.(Gnosticene Council Member) Schmierefische(Dopefish) Zollvurm(Inchworm) Leck(Guess!) KrankPilz(Mad Mushroom) Falstein(Mimrock) Giftschlamm(Poison slug) Schulefische(Guess again!) Himmelplage(Skypest) Kobald(Sprite) Sturmwolke(Thundercloud) Lcheln(Smirky, a.k.a Treasure Eater) and Bissen Bug.(Wormouth)

[quote]Quote:[hr]Commander Keen can be translated to Spanish as "Comandante Entusiasta" if I assume Keen is synonym of "enthusiast" in English.[hr][/quote]

Other synonyms would be eager, alert, ready... What we want is a Spanish word starting with 'c' or 'k'

[quote]Quote:[hr]None. They're only referred to plurally. What I just noticed, though, is that some enemies are described as "they," while others, such as Robo Red and Shelley, are referred to with "he" and "she."[hr][/quote]

Like German, English has a few inbuilt gendered words left, ships and countries are usually referred to as she or her, old sayings about mankind ususally just use 'man' such as 'Man, he is a social creature.' so the gender referred to in the games is unlikely to provide any clues to the actual gender of the enemies. Some, such as Shelley you would expect to be both genders (Although asexual all female populations are possible.) Whereas with others like Robo Red gender is unlikely and you can ascribe any one you want.

A similar problem occured with Death in the Discworld series by Pratchett, Death was originally nongendered and thus was translated freeley as either male or female depending on the tradition of that language (I believe in Spanish death is traditionally female?) but later books revealed he was male and things had to be changed.

[quote]Quote:[hr]One Shikadi, many Shikadi, I'd say.

Like Pokmon. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-lol.gif[/img] [hr][/quote]

Possibly, though Pokmon refers to a group of creatures rather than a single race. Here tradition is mixed, races can have plurals or not (1 Vorticon, 2 Vorticons vs 'the Vorticon homeworld' not 'The Vorticon's homeworld' either makes sense ad I personally think that yes, it's like Pokmon. We should ask Tom hall, along with the Smirky question.[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v499/Nevad/menbun.gif[/img]

Awww! Feel the love!
